Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: IRES: US-German research on human-computer interaction in ubiquitous computing
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical Abstract:
We have entered the era of ubiquitous computing, an era defined by interconnected devices embedded in everyday objects that become part of everyday activities. Ubiquitous computing, or ubicomp, is a multidisciplinary field of study that explores the design and implementation of embedded, networked computing devices. Interactions with the computational devices of the developing ubicomp world are challenging. Ubicomp researchers explore natural interactions with devices, using modalities such as speech, gaze, gestures, and touch. With these modes of interaction, the user's focus can remain primarily on the world surrounding the device. Human-computer interaction is a central issue in ubicomp, and it will be the focus of the work of the IRES students who will conduct research at two locations in Germany: at the University of Stuttgart, and at the University of Oldenburg.

Technical Abstract:
Our research will explore human-computer interaction in three areas of ubicomp: in-vehicle interactions, interactions with large displays, and interactions with devices on a ship bridge. We will explore user interfaces for highly automated vehicles, those that can take over all control of the vehicle for extended periods of time, and will signal well in advance when the driver needs to resume control. In these future vehicles, drivers will have ample time to devote to non-driving tasks. The design of the user interfaces will have less to do with the driver?s attention to the road (as is the case in today?s vehicles), and more with the physical characteristics of the vehicle (size, seating arrangement), the characteristics of the computing environment (network speed, quality of sensor readings), and the presence of other people in the vehicle and even in other vehicles (collaboration with other passengers, and distractions due to the activities of other passengers). Our goal is to explore how context should shape the design of in-vehicle user interfaces for automated vehicles. In our work with interfaces for ship bridges we will evaluate how to design interfaces that keep the human operator?s attention on the relevant interfaces and on the outside world, such that the operator can safely navigate the vessel. Our goal is to explore how to visualize relevant entities that are outside of the operator?s visual focus, and how to guide the operator?s shift of attention towards these entities for navigation and decision making. Finally, our work with large displays will explore the relationships between the characteristics of the user interfaces such as mode of interaction and context awareness, and measures such as user satisfaction, task completion time, and task completion quality. Our overarching goal is to establish some of these relationships, and use the results to propose improved designs of interactions with large displays.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This IRES program was a cooperative effort between the University of New Hampshire, Wellesley College, the University of Stuttgart in Germany, Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich in Germany, and the University of Oldenburg in Germany. The focus of the program was on human-computer interaction for ubiquitous computing environments. Ubiquitous computing is a multidisciplinary research area that explores networked computing devices that are embedded in everyday objects. We are learning how to provide users with information in a world where they are surrounded with computing devices, and where these computing devices are used in real environments, such as a ship, or a vehicle. We also study how to support users who are working from home. Furthermore, we have worked towards creating new knowledge in the area of virtual reality - expanding the reach of VR by introducing not only visual and audio elements, but haptic elements as well.

Over the four-year period between 2017 and 2021, a total of 21 students were supported by this grant. 18 of the students spent about nine weeks in Germany working in the labs of Prof. Susanne Boll and Prof. Albrecht Schmidt and supported by PIs Kun and Shaer. Student research in this IRES program advanced our knowledge of human-computer interaction in ubicomp environments. This included work on a number of projects, such as exploring haptic feedback in virtual reality, studying in-vehicle gesture-based interfaces, creating new interaction techniques in augmented reality, and using gaze for evaluating programing proficiency. We have disseminated the results of this broad effort through the publication of seven papers, five of which were co-authored by one or more IRES students, while two were co-authored by PIs Shaer and Kun, local hosts Schmidt and Boll, and two others.

The project had three key broader impacts. Most importantly, 21 undergraduate and graduate students from diverse backgrounds participated in project and gained research tools and skills while receiving mentorships. Most of the students also experienced life and work in a foreign country, learning to thrive in a new environment. The students created life-long professional and personal connections and showed that they can succeed in unfamiliar situations. Another lasting broader impact is a summer school series, co-organized by local hosts Boll and Schmidt, PIs Kun and Shaer, and others. The summer school ran for three years, interrupted by the COVID-19 pandemic, and was attended by students from Germany, the US, and other countries. Finally, PIs Kun and Shaer created a new series of online conversations with human-computer interaction experts. Participants included collaborators Prof. Boll and Schmidt as well alums of this program.
